span.span: UPDATED: April 27, 2020 @ 11:00am

During our district's extended closure due to COVID-19, our school nurse is readily available for virtual visits. Parents, students, and staff are welcome to contact the school nurse here for any health-related questions or concerns.
UPDATED: April 23, 2020 @ 8:00am

Today, the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin (PSC) launched a customer service phone line for people who need help locating phone or internet service during the COVID-19 public health emergency. Callers can speak with a PSC Consumer Affairs staff person who will walk through internet and phone service options
available in their area and discuss eligibility for discounts on critical communications services.
"The helpline will serve as a one-stop shop for Wisconsin residents. Now more than ever we need to equip our consumers with the information and resources they need in order
to access essential services," said Rebecca Cameron Valcq, Chairperson of the PSC.
The Internet and Phone Helpline number is 1 (608) 267-3595.
Callers can get help:
· Finding internet service and discounts
· Determining eligibility for a discount on voice or bundled voice and data service through the
Lifeline
program
· Finding locations where emergency Wi-Fi has been made available during the outbreak if no other options are available at home

Recently, the PSC in partnership with the Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction announced a new web tool that can be used to find now over 650 emergency Wi-Fi locations in the state. See that announcement
here
Additionally, the PSC has compiled a listing of emergency internet resources being offered by internet service providers. That information can be found on the PSC's website at

We hope that you are continuing to adjust well to our “new normal” of virtual learning. We thank you for your support and flexibility during this uncertain time. As promised, we want to continue to update you as new information becomes available. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has made a change that now allows the public broadcasting of Wi-Fi outside of buildings.
Throughout the week, our IT department has worked on implementing this change. We can now share that our WILMOT Wi-Fi network can be accessed outside the building in the south parking lot.

span.strong: Important information regarding WILMOT Wi-Fi Access:

span.span: Below you will see a picture that gives a rough outline of where the signal reaches (the southwest corner of the building, just outside Door B in the south parking lot).
Any community member can connect to the WILMOT Wi-Fi network without a password.
Any student using a District Chromebook will auto-connect to the appropriate Wi-Fi network as if they were inside the building.
The open WILMOT Wi-Fi network will be accessible from 6:00am - 10:00pm, 7 days a week.
Reminder: the building remains closed to students and community members. If using the WILMOT Wi-Fi network, please continue to practice social distancing and refrain from congregating in groups.

span.b: What is a Virtual Learning Day?

br.span: During school closure, Virtual Learning Days are days in which students will complete their instructional coursework at home in lieu of attending school. Students will need to utilize their school emails in order to communicate and connect with the virtual classrooms designed by their teachers. If you are using a home device, please use Google Chrome to log into your student’s account.

span.b: How will Wilmot Union High School teachers deliver instruction during Virtual Learning Days?

br.span: Most of our teachers will be utilizing Google Classroom as a virtual learning application. Our Physical Education and Business Information Technology departments are well versed in Schoology and will continue to use that application. Each teacher will contact students via email with specific information about joining their class virtually.

span.b: What if my student does not have a device or connectivity?

br.span: If you need a device to take part in virtual learning, please report to the high school on Tuesday, March 17 between the hours of 8:00 am and 3:00 pm. Please try to have your student ID on you. If you do not have your student ID, you must know your student ID number.

span.b: What will the daily schedule be?

br.span: l Learning will begin on Wednesday, March 18, 2020. *Please note there will be no Virtual Learning Days during our previously scheduled Spring Break (March 23-March 27).* Virtual Learning will resume on Monday, March 30, 2020.

p.span: Virtual Learning Days will focus on the essential information that students will need to ensure the continuation of learning. Teachers will be creating approximately 30-45 minute lessons per class. The 30-45 minute lessons may include activities, reading, videos, writing, formative assessments, and/or discussions, etc.

Students should plan approximately 3 hours total per day of engagement in the learning tasks. Teacher prep time is 7:35am-9:00am. Tasks will be posted by 9:00 am daily and will follow the schedule below:

span.b: Even Days of the Month: 2nd, 4th, 6th, and 8th hours

p.b: Odd Days of the Month: 1st, 3rd, 5th, and 7th hours

br.span: For each course on the assigned days, students are expected to:

span.span: 1. Go into their assigned class’ Google Classroom/Schoology Classroom
2. Read through the information posted by the teacher
3. Complete the learning tasks as instructed by the teacher
4. Repeat 1-3 for each course assigned following the schedule above.

p.span: Teachers will be posting specific hours that they will be available through their virtual applications or via email. Teachers and school counselors will have availability throughout the hours of 7:35am-2:30pm for email responses. Please be patient with teachers/counselors as they respond. Sometimes questions require more time to respond to, or teachers may be working with another student at the time of receiving the email.

br.span: ime of shutdown, students are going to receive to the greatest extent possible the services they need to continue their education. Special Education teachers and other Pupil Services staff will be available to work with students via phone, email, and zoom. Your Special Education Case Manager will work with each of their students to plan for needs and Susan Fennell is available for any 504 students or parents who have questions about need.

span.span: Special Education teachers are still partnering in their Co-Taught classes to make sure that students are receiving the support and differentiated instruction that they need.

This will be available Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays starting 3/17/2020. This service will not be available over our regularly scheduled spring break.

span.b: What if I have more questions?

br.span: The best option would be to start specifically with the teacher of the class in which you have the question. If the question extends beyond the classroom teacher, all counselors and administration will be available to families during this time.

We understand that things may not always go as planned and that things may happen that are outside of your control. Please keep the lines of communication open with your student’s teacher(s) if you run into an extenuating circumstance so they can help adjust the learning experience to help support the circumstance.
Thank you for your continued support and patience during this challenging time.

Updated: March 13, 2020 @ 5:12pm CST

Together, we are facing an unprecedented health crisis in our community. We have been in constant communication with the Kenosha County Health Department, which is monitoring the guidance from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC). Today, Governor Evers ordered a mandatory closure of all Wisconsin schools effective Wednesday, March 18. As a precautionary measure against the transmission of novel coronavirus (COVID-19), Wilmot Union High School will be closing effective immediately.

p.span: Beginning Monday, March 16, 2020, all school building activities including school day instruction, before and after-school activities, all athletic and extracurricular practices, competitions, and weekend events are canceled. Our Community Outreach classes are also canceled and our Fitness Center will remain closed until further notice.

We know that closing our school will impact all families, and we recognize that working families depend on the consistency and predictability of supports and services our school offers. This includes educational, emotional, and nutritional supports. We also recognize there are still a lot of unknowns about this disease and just how prevalent it is in our community. As novel coronavirus (COVID-19) testing becomes more readily available, these cases will likely increase. While children appear to be more protected from extreme symptoms, adults, including our educators and employees, need support and protection as well.

At this time, we are notifying our families regarding the closure. By March 18, we will be sending further communication regarding implementing virtual learning and answers to additional questions. More information will be communicated as soon as it is available.

Updated: March 12, 2020

We want to let you know that Wilmot Union High School is closely monitoring this rapidly-changing situation regarding the spread of the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19). Naturally, it is a concern when we hear about health-related events like this. While there are currently no known cases of the virus in our area, we are proactively working to have a plan should it be needed. Please be assured that the health and safety of our students and staff is always our top priority.

This is not the first time the District has had to think about how to keep students learning if schools were to be closed. We all remember the Polar Vortex. We are updating our pandemic crisis plan as well as asking teachers and administrators to start thinking about how we would keep students learning in the event schools close due to the spread of the Coronavirus. We recognize that distance learning may not work for every student and every family due to connectivity issues, special needs, and other circumstances; as a result, we ask that you complete this

b.span: If unable to access and/or complete the survey, please reach out to your student’s counselor to develop plans to meet your needs if assessing information and resources digitally is an issue.

span.span: Our district follows the advice of local and state health authorities. At this time, they have not recommended school closure. Should that change, we will follow their recommendation.

This is a time when we need to be sensitive to our students and staff members who have family members in countries being impacted by the Coronavirus. We need to work together to help students and staff understand that this is a very real concern for some of their fellow Panthers. In no circumstance is it appropriate for staff, students, or visitors to the school to make derisive comments about those who are impacted by the virus, or to “joke” about it. If you feel you need additional support due to family circumstances, please do not hesitate to reach out.
Our Building & Grounds department is committed to both regular cleaning and increased disinfection of our building. The following precautions have been taken:
50 additional hand sanitizer stations have been installed throughout the building.
Surfaces are being cleaned with two different disinfectants as a part of daily cleaning.
Electrostatic Handheld Disinfectant Sprayers are being used throughout the building; including in the Fitness Center.
Our Food Service Provider, Taher, is also closely monitoring the situation and taking the following precautions:
Changing all salad bar, side bar, and pizza station utensils after first lunch.
Disinfecting all surfaces before and after each lunch.
Using single service gloves
Thorough training in safe food handling procedures and hand washing.
We urge everyone to continue the practice of maintaining healthy behaviors necessary during any cold and flu season. These include but are not limited to:
Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, or cough or sneeze into your inner elbow;
Practice good hand washing with soap and water as often as possible, and if soap and water are not available, use alcohol-based hand sanitizers;
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces;
If your student begins to have flu like symptoms at school have them report to the nurse’s office as soon as possible to be evaluated
Please stay home when you are sick and keep your student home if they are sick.
We will share updates when new information or guidelines need to be communicated. Thank you for your continued support during this situation.
